激发您灵感的 14 个微距摄影创意帖子首先出现在数码摄影学校。它的作者是杰梅斯·登普西 (Jaymes Dempsey) 。

本文于 2023 年 12 月更新，由 Jaymes Dempsey、 Darren Rowse 、 Bruce Lovelace和Darlene Hildebrandt贡献。

您是否正在努力想出令人惊叹的微距摄影创意？您需要一点创造力的启动吗？您来对地方了。作为一名经验丰富的微距摄影师，我已经拍摄了数百个甚至数千个微距主题，并且在此过程中我遇到了很多很棒的想法。

下面，我分享了我最喜欢的 14 个令人惊叹的微距拍摄创意，包括在室外和家里拍摄的创意。我确保包含各种主题的选项：花朵、昆虫、水滴、家居用品等等。

您准备好开始捕捉一些令人惊叹的微距图像了吗？然后让我们直接讨论我的第一个想法：

1.尝试水滴折射摄影

水滴折射摄影是微距经典摄影，您可以在室内和室外进行尝试。这个概念很简单，但却产生了令人惊叹的结果。首先找到一个细长的物体，比如一片草叶或一根花茎。然后，使用喷雾瓶轻轻添加水滴，直到它们摇摇欲坠地悬挂在边缘。

当您将一个彩色物体放在水滴后面几英寸处时，例如鲜艳的花朵或彩虹色的纸，就会发生奇迹。这个背景主题将通过水滴进行美丽的折射，在每个水滴中创建一个微型的、颠倒的图像。当你靠近时——我建议使用微距镜头！ – 聚焦在水滴上，背景会变得模糊，将观看者的注意力吸引到微小的、封装的场景上。

要在保持模糊背景的同时实现水滴的清晰度，需要稳定的手和一点耐心。在这些情况下，三脚架的作用非常大，它可以帮助稳定相机以拍摄完美的照片。但结果总是值得的：一张令人着迷、近乎超现实的照片，展示了主题中的主题！

2. 拍摄眼睛

近距离拍摄眼睛是一种令人着迷的体验，如果您被困在室内，这也是一个很棒的微距摄影创意。首先，找到一个愿意的主题（可以是从家庭成员到宠物的任何人！）。确保他们对这个过程感到满意，因为这项技术要求他们保持静止一段时间。

使用微距镜头，靠近拍摄对象的眼睛，然后仔细注意您所看到的内容。每只眼睛都是一个自己的世界，具有独特的纹理和色调。尝试不同的角度和灯光。侧面照明可以突出眼睛的纹理，而正面照明可以突出微小的细节。请记住，关键是耐心和实验。

多拍几张。微距摄影是一场精度和运气的游戏。只要注意拍摄对象的舒适度即可，不要过度。如果一切顺利，您最终将获得令人惊叹的眼睛特写镜头，揭示其内部令人惊叹的宇宙！

3.拍摄羽毛

当我第一次开始微距摄影时，我非常喜欢拍摄羽毛——我想你也会的！羽毛有着复杂的图案和鲜艳的色彩，成为令人着迷的宏观主题，而且它们很容易接近；我建议您从当地的杂货店购买一些孔雀羽毛，尽管您总是可以拍摄外出散步时发现的羽毛！ （只要确保好好清洁它们并洗手——就像所有事情一样，安全总比后悔好！）

不管怎样，无论是散步时收集的还是购买的，关键是要选择颜色更吸引眼球的羽毛。我还建议选择较大的羽毛，特别是如果您没有专用的微距镜头。

从不同角度拍摄羽毛可以提供不同的视角。自上而下的视图使您可以清晰地捕捉整个羽毛，突出其对称之美和详细的结构。或者，从较低角度和浅景深拍摄羽毛会产生艺术模糊效果，只有一小部分羽毛清晰对焦。这种技术利用了观众的感知，将一根简单的羽毛变成了强调形式和纹理的抽象微距镜头。

请记住，灯光在微距羽毛摄影中起着至关重要的作用。柔和的漫射光可以展现精致的细节，而更具戏剧性的定向照明可以增强纹理并创造有趣的阴影。因此，请确保尝试各种不同的方法，直到获得您喜欢的结果。

4. 提出一个主题

这里有一个想法：不要将自己限制在单一主题上，而是采取主题方法。如果你选择纹理作为开发主题会怎么样？现在花点时间记下任何你能想到的有质感的东西。深吸一口气，放松，闭上眼睛，放空思绪。

使用如下图所示的思维导图。这只是一种产生创造性可能性的头脑风暴方法。这里只是四个随机的例子。这些可能会导致其他切线的想法，所以写下你所有的想法并稍后编辑你的列表！

5. 寻找背景中的灯光以获得令人惊叹的散景效果

进行创意微距摄影的最佳方法之一是捕捉华丽的散景。也就是说，美丽、光滑、奶油色的背景，就像下一张图片中的模糊效果一样：

操作方法如下：

首先，找到一个你真正喜欢的主题。一朵花、一只昆虫或一些植物都可以很好地发挥作用。选择大光圈（f/2.8 至 f/5.6 范围内的光圈）。然后放大，直到仅分离出主题。

重要的部分来了：

慢慢地围绕拍摄对象移动，同时通过相机的取景器进行观察。关键是找到一个“产生散景”的背景。

现在，散景生成背景涉及光。最好的散景通常来自背景中明亮的灯光和颜色。更具体地说，寻找光的针刺和彩色反射。

例如，阳光穿过树木会产生令人惊叹的散景——因为树木会分解光线。

黄金时段光线下的树叶也会产生华丽的散景。树叶上的金色光芒反射，形成奶油色、色彩缤纷的背景。

大多数场景至少有一些散景选项 - 所以不要满足于低于标准的选择。

相反，使用散景来创造杰作！

6. 在阳光下拍摄华丽的逆光微距摄影

自然摄影师经常使用顺光拍摄——光线从摄影师的肩膀上方射出，落在拍摄对象上。

这通常效果很好。但过了一段时间就会变得无聊。

如果您想发挥创意，请尝试使用背光。

背光来自拍摄对象的后面。它非常适合创建剪影，也非常适合产生创意灯光效果。

光线可以穿过拍摄对象的一部分，使其变成半透明。

背光还可以产生明亮的光斑。如果做得正确，这会产生一些令人惊叹的效果。

但是，您应该仔细放置太阳。

如果你的画面中出现了裸露的太阳，整个镜头就会被毁掉，因为太阳太亮了，你的相机无法渲染。

相反，请将微距摄影主体放在太阳前面。这样，太阳就被挡住了。但你仍然会得到一些华丽的效果。

事实上，我建议尝试一下。尝试稍微改变角度，使太阳位于拍摄对象的不同部分后面。

您将设法捕捉一些令人惊叹的镜头 - 您最初可能无法想象的镜头！

7. 摄影用具

您是否考虑过您的餐具抽屉的艺术潜力？令人惊讶的是，您在那里找到的银器可以成为明星微距照片的主题！

您可以使用几种不同的方法。例如，通过关注这些日常物体并从上方拍摄，您可以制作令人惊叹的特写平躺照片。简单的白色或黑色背景将突出它们的形状和线条，将普通的叉子和勺子变成有趣的主题。

然而，我更偏向于另一种方法，即放大器具的单个部分，并享受捕捉不同抽象风格的镜头的乐趣。找到一个引人注目的焦点——比如叉子的尖端——然后让器具的其余部分变得模糊，创造出一种迷人的焦点和抽象效果。

这个宏观想法的美妙之处在于它的简单性和主题的容易获得的性质！

8. 在白色天空下拍摄，打造华丽高调的外观

这是我最喜欢的微距摄影创意。

我每次有困难的时候都会用它！

幸运的是，它非常简单：

在白色的天空下拍摄。

让我解释：

微距照片最重要的部分之一是背景。如果没有漂亮的背景，您的微距照片通常会很平淡。

现在，最好的背景是简单而统一的。

创建统一背景的好方法之一是什么？

靠天！

这在阴天尤其有效。你所要做的就是找到一个主题——然后低调。事实上，你常常必须低于你的拍摄对象。

确保背景完全被云层覆盖。

然后拍摄您的拍摄对象并观看它在华丽的白色背景下脱颖而出！

（如果镜头稍微太暗，请不要担心。您随时可以在后期处理中提升白色。）

9. 捕获蒲公英种子头

蒲公英种子头是微距摄影师的宝库。这些常见的园林植物在微距镜头下变成了迷人的拍摄对象。首先选择一个大的种子头（越大越好；更大的主题可以更近距离、更详细地观察每颗精致的种子）。

在微距镜头允许的范围内尽可能放大。这里的目标是利用种子头的自然设计。其流畅的线条和重复的图案可以创造出视觉上令人愉悦的构图。尝试以引导观看者的眼睛浏览图像的方式排列种子。

此外，互补的背景也很重要，为了增加一点额外的风格，可以在种子头上轻轻喷水。这个简单的技巧将添加精致的水滴，增强整体效果！

10. Freelens 实现令人惊叹的选择性对焦

当你陷入困境时，这是另一个很棒的微距摄影创意：

自由镜头！

我是这种技术的超级粉丝——因为它能产生引人注目的、独特的图像。

它的工作原理如下：

打开相机，并确保镜头聚焦到无限远。

然后关闭相机并拆下镜头。

（我建议您为此使用倒车摄像头和倒车镜头，因为存在损坏设备的风险。）

现在，最适合微距自由镜头的镜头是 50 毫米范围。我发现50 毫米可以在背景模糊和清晰对焦之间取得良好的平衡。

卸下镜头后，重新打开相机。

然后…

实验！

注意：使用自由镜头时，您无需通过转动对焦环进行对焦。相反，您可以通过改变镜头相对于相机的位置来对焦。

因此，请保持镜头分离，并以不同角度移动它。

寻找微距拍摄对象，看看使用自由镜头设置拍摄它们时会发生什么。另外，请注意将镜头拉离相机会如何增加镜头的放大倍率。它还允许更多的光线进入——创造艺术漏光！

自由镜头有点让人上瘾。一旦开始，您将很难停下来 - 因为有很多机会拍摄华丽的微距照片！

11. 通过第二个拍摄对象拍摄令人难以置信的前景

如果您想要特别有创意的微距摄影的想法……

......为什么不尝试“射击”或“临时抱佛脚”？

首先，找一个宏观的主题。鲜花尤其适合这一点，因为它们色彩缤纷。

靠近并将镜头聚焦在该主题上。选择 f/2.8 至 f/5.6 范围内的大光圈。

然后找到第二个主题。将其放在镜头前。第二个主题应该是丰富多彩的——理想情况下，与第一个主题相似。

还有……射击！

第二个主题（仍然处于焦点之外）将创建一个美丽的前景水洗。在微距摄影中看起来很棒的一款。

现在，您不想让前景主体完全覆盖镜头。相反，将其部分放入场景中。这样，它就能创造出漂亮的水洗效果，而不会主导镜头。

这可能需要一些实验。但如果您有耐心，您会捕捉到一些精美的微距照片。

你的创造力将会变得充满活力！

12.拍摄弦乐器

你家里有弦乐器吗？它可能只是您的下一个伟大的宏观主题。吉他、小提琴或班卓琴等乐器具有独特的几何图案，当通过微距镜头观察时，这些图案变得非常明显。

一种令人着迷的方法是从较低的角度拍摄琴弦。这样，您可以突出显示琴弦的一小部分，同时让其余部分模糊到背景中。结果？聚焦与模糊的迷人表演。

为了增强你的拍摄效果，请注意灯光。自然光会产生奇迹，尤其是当它突出乐器的轮廓时。我建议从窗户灯开始，但如果有的话，您可以随时使用热靴灯或闪光灯。请记住：每种照明设置都可以极大地改变照片的情绪和感觉！

13.尝试拍摄蚂蚁

蚂蚁虽然经常被忽视，但却是令人着迷的微距摄影主题。这些小生物充满个性，而且非常上镜。

您的后院或当地的公园是理想的地点；首先趴在地上寻找在树叶或草叶上爬行的蚂蚁。蚂蚁越大，微距拍摄效果越好。

一旦找到一两个拍摄对象，就拿出相机并近距离对焦。切换到手动对焦，然后前后摇动相机以在跟踪拍摄对象时保持对焦。

请记住，拍摄蚂蚁需要耐心。在高倍率下，蚂蚁的移动速度快得惊人，因此要做好多拍的准备。这在一定程度上只是一场数字游戏：您拍摄的照片越多，捕捉到一些特殊照片的机会就越大。

并尝试将蚂蚁隔离在框架中。简单的背景下，一只蚂蚁就能产生强烈的视觉冲击力！

14.捕获油漆

微距摄影可以将日常物品转化为抽象艺术，绘画就是一个完美的例子。对于这个宏观想法，任何油漆都可以完成工作，但我建议从充满活力的厚油漆开始，以获得更多的纹理和颜色对比度。

首先在纸上旋转颜料。目标是创造一种有趣的颜色组合，但又不会过度混合。第一次尝试这个想法时，粗而粗的笔画是理想的选择。您想要保持具有有趣的漩涡和重叠的不同颜色区域。

然后，一旦您对自己的创作感到满意，请将其设置在光线充足的地方（最好靠近窗户以获得自然照明）。最后，用微距镜头探索您所创造的多彩风景。重点关注颜色流动的区域或油漆形成有趣图案的区域。

请记住，每个镜头都可以成为独特的抽象构图，充满色彩和纹理。微距镜头将捕捉肉眼无法看到的细节，将您的颜料漩涡转变成迷人的宏观世界！

微距摄影创意：下一步

希望您现在对拍摄一些自己的微距照片感到兴奋。毕竟，您对于原创、创意镜头有很多想法！

关键是开始将它们付诸实践。因此，拿起近焦镜头，从这个列表中选择一个主题或技术想法，然后享受乐趣！

本文于 2023 年 12 月更新，由 John McIntire 和Russell Masters贡献。

灯光可以成就或毁掉一幅肖像。根据我的经验，它通常可以将普通快照变成具有专业外观的图像。翻盖照明是一种简单而强大的技术，它可以将您的摄影提升到一个新的水平。

但什么是翻盖照明？如何掌握翻盖式照明设置以获得令人惊叹的效果？

在这篇文章中，我将解释这个简单但功能极其强大的两灯人像设置的细节。从尝试不同的修改器到使用灯光位置等等，我将探索所有细节以帮助您掌握这种美妙的照明技术。当您读完本文时，您将了解如何像专业人士一样创建翻盖式照明肖像（无论您的照明设备如何！）。

因此，如果您准备好成为翻盖肖像大师，那么让我们从基础知识开始吧：

什么是翻盖照明？

翻盖式照明是一种简单的双灯配置：您可以将两盏灯以 45 度角面向拍摄对象，一盏灯向上，一盏灯向下。请注意，主光（即主光、较亮的光）应向下 45 度，而辅助光应向上 45 度。您的相机应位于两盏灯之间，面向拍摄对象。

从侧面看，两个灯就像一个打开的蛤壳（可能需要想象力！）：

翻盖式设置可提供美丽、柔和的光线、微弱的阴影和绚丽的聚光灯。翻盖式照明几乎适合所有人；我想说，它适合所有年龄段的男士和女士，因此非常适合放在你的后口袋里。

请注意，翻盖照明就像蝴蝶照明一样，只不过您在主体下方添加了补光（这可以消除由主光造成的任何重阴影）。因此，如果您已经在进行蝴蝶设置，则可以随时在末尾添加翻盖式外观以进行一些变化！

如何创建翻盖式照明设置：分步过程

创建翻盖式照明设置非常简单，只要您有两个工作灯，几乎就可以保证成功。这就是你要做的：

第 1 步：选择灯光和调节器

翻盖式照明需要两个光源，可以是工作室闪光灯或热靴闪光灯（经过修改或未经修改）。

就我个人而言，我建议您使用工作室闪光灯。虽然热靴灯也很好，但它们在两次拍摄之间的回收时间稍长，因此您将无法进行快速人像摄影。 （闪光灯的另一个好处是它们通常包括造型灯，这是一种低功率连续灯，可以在您设置时照亮您的拍摄对象，并可以帮助您确定完美的照明角度。）

我还建议您使用修饰符- 这将有助于柔化光线以获得更漂亮的效果 - 并且抓住一对类似大小的柔光箱是一个很好的起点。 （如果您没有柔光箱，您可以尝试使用雨伞作为主灯。）

也就是说，如果您没有任何修饰符或者您喜欢更硬的外观，那么请使用未修饰的灯光！如果您真正接受这种效果并根据需要对其进行雕刻，您可能会得到很好的结果。另外，这是你的照片！

第 2 步：放置主光

抓住你的主光（即你的主光源）。目标是将其放置在拍摄对象的前面并稍稍上方；将其向下倾斜，使其直接指向拍摄对象的鼻子。

如果您想要具有快速光线衰减的柔和效果，请将光线靠近拍摄对象的脸部。如果您想要更强烈的效果来更广泛地照亮拍摄对象，请将灯光移得更远。

接下来， 测光您所需的光圈（我们将使用假设的 f/11）并进行测试拍摄。

如果一切设置正确，您应该生成一个光线充足的图像，在拍摄对象的鼻子和下巴下方有很深的阴影。 （如果图像太暗，请随意调亮灯光，如果图像曝光过度，请执行相反的操作。）

第 3 步：添加补光灯

现在是时候添加第二盏灯了；将补光灯直接放置在主光下方，以 45 度角向上指向拍摄对象。

调整灯光的亮度，直到其位于主光下方两档。 （如果您想以 f/11 拍摄，您可以测量补光以获得 f/5.6 的结果。）然后进行第二次测试拍摄。

如果效果太强并且补光消除了阴影，请调低灯光功率。如果灯光效果不够，请将其打开。需要注意的主要问题是辅助光压倒了主光，因为这会导致从下方照亮的图像非常不美观。

第 4 步：拍摄翻盖图像！

此时，您应该有两个灯光共享相同的垂直空间，并且顶部的灯光应比底部的灯光亮大约两档。

站在灯光后面，从缝隙中拍摄。注意：如果没有太大的间隙，请升高和/或降低两个灯，直到有足够的空间在中间拍摄。为了安全起见，您可能需要再次抄表。

当然，一旦您拍摄了一两张照片，请检查相机的液晶显示屏是否存在曝光问题和其他问题。如果您有能力，我建议您将相机连接到笔记本电脑；这样，您就可以在大屏幕上立即查看图像。

这就是全部！翻盖式照明确实很容易实现，通过一些练习，您将能够在几分钟内运行两灯设置。

翻盖式照明与蝴蝶式照明

蝴蝶照明和翻盖照明经常一起讨论，但它们是两种截然不同的照明模式。

基本的蝴蝶照明设置仅使用一盏灯，位于主体上方并向下倾斜。由于没有补光，鼻子和下巴上的阴影仍然很重，从而产生更加戏剧性和强烈的效果。这种效果特别适合时尚摄影。

现在，让我们将其与翻盖照明进行比较。翻盖照明涉及在拍摄对象下方放置第二盏灯，以柔化阴影。这会产生更柔和、更舒缓的效果，因此经常出现在传统的爆头摄影或戏剧性少得多的应用中。

专业提示：如果您不确定想要的最终外观，可以随时从蝴蝶照明开始。尝试一下阴影和角度，然后如果您想要更柔和的东西，只需添加补光即可实现翻盖式外观。这样，您就可以轻松地尝试两种不同的照明风格。这是一种方便且富有创意的人像照明方法。

蛤壳式照明与伦勃朗照明

另一种值得考虑的经典照明技术？ 伦勃朗灯光。伦勃朗图案需要将光线放置在拍摄对象的侧面（通常大约 45 度），以在拍摄对象的脸颊上形成清晰的三角形光线。

由于伦勃朗光线将脸部的大部分区域覆盖在阴影中，因此伦勃朗光线以其黑暗和喜怒无常的品质而闻名。它是那些在图像中寻求戏剧性、戏剧风格的人的最爱。

那么翻盖式照明如何与伦勃朗相比呢？如果您想要拍摄更欢快、更细致的照片，翻盖式照明是更好的选择。通过将灯光放置在拍摄对象的上方和下方，您可以更均匀地照亮脸部并减少刺眼的阴影。这可以展现出更多的面部细节，让图像更加生动、更加平易近人。

简而言之，如果您的目标是戏剧和情绪，伦勃朗的照明可能是必经之路。但是，对于更令人振奋和详细的肖像，Clamshell Lighting适合该法案。了解这些照明技术的细微差别将使您可以为每个唯一的肖像会话选择正确的样式。尝试两者，看看您的想法！

翻盖式摄影设置：一些快速提示

您知道如何捕获基本的翻盖式图像。但是，如何进一步拍摄呢？以下是我的一些主要技巧可以帮助您：

1.尝试不同的修饰符

当您首先从剪镜照明开始时，软箱可能是您最好的朋友。它们提供了一种适合初学者的柔和感。但是，随着您变得更加舒适，您可能会发现自己想探索其他选择。这是一个好主意。

您想使用一对脱衣舞箱吗？大胆试试吧。是否想将美容菜作为钥匙灯和雨伞作为填充？当然。 鼻子和一个小柔软的箱子怎么样？绝对地。使用您手头的东西。很快，您将能够像专业人士一样即兴创作。

例如，美容菜会创造出更难的外观，可以为肖像增添戏剧性。他们的聚光灯可以突出纹理和细节。另一方面，雨伞确实可以使阴影变软。通过大量光线，它们使一切感觉更加散布和空灵。

通过测试不同的修饰符，您将了解它们如何影响您的图像。因此，不要害怕尝试新事物。只需记住要牢记剪镜照明的本质：使肖像闪耀的美丽，讨人喜欢的光芒。

2.尝试重新定位灯

光线位置在翻盖式照明中很重要，甚至几英寸的调整也可以极大地改变最终图像。

将灯光移至靠近您的主题，阴影会变软并变得更加评分，以使外观柔和而细腻。

将灯光移离您的主题，阴影将变硬并变得更加清晰。这可以为图像增添深度和戏剧性。

但这不只是距离。您可以将钥匙灯移动更高以创建更长的阴影或更低的阴影以创建较短的阴影。您可以使用填充灯做同样的事情。

不要谨慎不要过分。我在第一步中讨论的45度职位旨在看起来很讨人喜欢。使用定位很棒，但不要忽视您的原始目标！

3.添加更多灯

一旦您正确设置了翻盖式照明，您可能会认为自己已经完成了。但是，您可以做更多的事情来增强场景并创建引人注目的图像。

例如，您可以在主体后面或两侧添加轮辋灯，以在头部周围创建一片精致的光线。此效果将帮助您的主题弹出背景，并使图像更具动态性。

发光可以为您的照片增加深度。它位于受试者的上方和后面，它在头发上巧妙地闪耀，将其与背景分开。

请不要犹豫，尝试背景灯。将光线放置在主题后面（指向背景）可以产生美丽的光锥，从而增加额外的深度。这是多少摄影师将光线充足的主题与光线充足的背景相结合！

最重要的是：通过添加这些额外的灯光，您可以为自己提供更多的创意自由，并在剪盖照明设置中打开可能性的世界。

4.转换为黑白

Clamshell Lighting会产生精美的图像，在颜色和黑色和白色方面看起来都令人惊叹。将您的镜头转换为黑白，将强调阴影和亮点的相互作用，同时可能在照片中增加三维性。

如果您以RAW射击，我强烈建议您这样做，那么您可以灵活地使用相机的单色模式拍照，并且在需要时仍可以转换回颜色。或者，您可以从颜色开始，然后再转换为黑白。

黑白转换可以使脸部的特征以独特的方式脱颖而出。它可能会带出纹理，强调对比度，甚至会产生一种颜色不会捕捉的心情。尝试这种转换使您可以探索单个照明设置中的一系列视觉表达式，这总是一个好主意！

5.观看守望灯

捕捉是主体眼中的那个神奇的光线，它是由光源的反射创造的。它带给眼睛。没有守望灯，眼睛和整个肖像可能看起来平坦而毫无生气。

因此，重要的是要始终确保翻盖照片包含角光！如果不存在角色，您可能需要要求您的主题向他们的头部倾斜，或者您可能需要对灯光进行一些调整。确保查看相机LCD上的每次测试镜头，以确保捕获灯与您想要的相同。

请注意，使用剪镜照明，由于它涉及两个灯而不是一个灯，您可能会注意到双关节灯。这是一些摄影师喜欢的功能，而其他人则不太热情。

如果您不喜欢底极的粉丝，请不要担心！在后处理过程中，它总是可以克隆出来。

美丽风景建筑摄影的 9 个技巧首先出现在数码摄影学校。它的作者是杰里米·弗林特。

建筑风景摄影是一种独特且具有挑战性的流派，融合了风景和建筑摄影的元素。它涉及捕捉建筑环境中的景观和自然景观中的建筑物，如果您知道正确的方法，结果可能会令人惊叹！

在这篇文章中，我提供了大量拍摄建筑景观的实用技巧，重点是装备选择、构图、灯光和规划。无论您是寻求增强建筑景观图像的中级还是高级摄影师，本指南都可以为您提供帮助 - 因此，如果您准备好提升您的镜头水平，请继续阅读！

1.使用广角镜头

正如我上面提到的，风景建筑摄影涉及在同一帧中捕捉建筑物和风景。尽管这种类型的图像有很多令人惊叹的例子，但获得一流的结果可能比看起来要复杂一些。

您首先需要选择合适的设备，虽然您的相机不会产生很大的影响，但广角镜头是必不可少的。它可以让您在画面中包含更多元素，这在拍摄大型建筑结构和重要景观特征时特别有用。

此外，广角镜头可以为有趣的前景元素（例如植被或路径）留出空间，从而帮助您增加景观建筑主题的深度。

也就是说，更宽的焦距确实会导致垂直方向的汇聚——直线向内倾斜——虽然可以在后处理中纠正这种透视失真，但我实际上建议采用不同的方法：

2.尝试移轴镜头

垂直会聚是建筑摄影中的一个常见问题。当平行线（例如由建筑物墙壁创建的平行线）向图像中心倾斜时，就会发生这种透视变形。不幸的结果是垂直的物体看起来向后落下。

在后期处理中纠正这个问题可能具有挑战性，但移轴镜头的设计可以在按下快门按钮之前解决这个问题。移轴镜头对于拉直建筑风景摄影中的线条特别有效，因为通过小心地水平或垂直移动镜头，您可以拉直建筑物的边缘以及景观中向内倾斜的树木。

移轴镜头比传统玻璃镜头更昂贵，而且没有太多选择 - 但如果您认真拍摄风景建筑，购买 TS 型号通常值得付出成本和降低灵活性。

（也就是说，在某些情况下，保留线条原样可能有利于图像的构图！因此，如果您不想使用移轴镜头，或者您只是碰巧看到一个透视效果更好的场景失真，请随意使用更传统的方法。）

3.融入花卉和植物

当您观察有趣的建筑时，您是否曾停下来欣赏花园或周围景观中令人惊叹的花草？建筑奇观周围的植物群 - 无论是宫殿、城堡还是城市摩天大楼 - 都可以为您的照片增添趣味。

由于花朵是季节性的，并且通常只能持续两到十二周，因此如果您想在花朵盛开时捕捉它们，时机至关重要。例如，许多雪花莲通常出现在冬天，水仙花出现在春天，薰衣草出现在夏天。

将这些元素融入到您的照片中可以增强整体场景，甚至使建筑看起来更加突出，因此请做好研究并尝试在花园处于最佳状态时拍摄！

4.考虑光线

照明对风景建筑摄影的效果有很大影响；根据光线质量和角度，您可以捕捉戏剧性的轮廓、柔和的风景、高对比度的建筑轮廓等。

对于景观建筑主题来说，没有单一的最佳光线类型，因此尝试不同的照明条件是一个好主意，尤其是当您刚刚开始时。白天提供了在阴天或明亮阳光下捕捉场景的机会，这些场景看起来不错，但缺乏戏剧性。另一方面，清晨和下午晚些时候的拍摄可以突出阴影，增加文件的深度。

日落后拍摄是另一个绝佳的选择，因为人造建筑灯光和昏暗的天空相结合可以产生令人惊叹的效果。

基本上，您有很多选择，因此关键是在各种照明场景下携带相机，然后简单地拍摄令您着迷的场景。随着时间的推移，您将获得对某些类型的光线的洞察力和鉴赏力，并且您可以将其作为跳板，拍摄出更好的照片！

5. 构图很重要！

风景建筑摄影中的构图常常被忽视，而倾向于令人惊叹的主题和戏剧性的光线。那是一个错误。构图是风景建筑摄影的一个重要方面，因为画面中元素的放置可以显着影响图像的效果。

因此，在按下快门按钮之前，您必须仔细思考每一帧的构图。

例如，对称性可以是一种强大的构图工具。您可以通过将图像分为两个相似的顶部和底部部分来创建水平对称，也可以通过中心线在两侧创建镜像来创建垂直对称。

6.记住三分法

虽然对称构图在某些情况下可能很有效，而且这是一种可以放在后兜里的好技术，但我不建议将对称作为首选构图方法。

相反，在进行风景建筑摄影时，应用三分法则通常会产生更好的效果。该技术涉及使用两条水平线和两条垂直线将图像分成九个相等的部分。通过将主要拍摄对象放置在偏离中心的位置（沿着网格线或在其交叉点处），您可以获得更具视觉吸引力和影响力的照​​片。

7. 构图主题

在构图的前景中添加一个框架是一个经典的技巧，在拍摄风景中的建筑时效果非常好！

框架可以由任何自然或人造元素创建，例如围绕主要拍摄对象的树木、窗户或灌木丛，甚至只是引导观看者的眼睛进入镜头。这种技术不仅可以创造对比度，还可以通过合并突出和补充主要主题的前景元素来增加构图的深度。

8.花时间计划

在毫无准备的情况下到达一个地点，很难捕捉到引人注目的图像。研究和规划是关键；在这些早期阶段，您可以识别有趣的主题，并根据所需的照明条件确定最佳拍摄时间。

如果可能的话，在计划拍照前几个小时（或几天）步行寻找地点。考虑不同的组合。考虑太阳的位置及其对场景的影响。

如果您无法亲自查看某个位置，请花一些时间在谷歌上搜索该主题的其他图像，或者至少在谷歌地图上“开车”经过。列出您可能有兴趣创建的镜头列表。

但在真正的拍摄过程中，不要过于专注于计划，以免错过任何出色的自发机会。换句话说，花时间计划，但要灵活、适应性强！

9.使用三脚架

三脚架是捕获景观建筑照片的重要工具。它在任何光线下都很有用，但在弱光条件下使用三脚架尤其重要。

如果您拍摄日落图像、蓝色时刻图像或夜间图像，三脚架将确保您的文件清晰锐利。这样，您就可以专注于拍摄构图良好、光线充足的照片，而不必太担心手持时保持较快的快门速度。

只要确保您不会花钱购买不耐用的廉价三脚架即可。对于三脚架，通常最好预先投入大量现金，而不是花 50 美元购买三脚架，然后在几个月内被迫升级。

风景建筑摄影：最后的话

无论您是初学者、中级甚至是旨在提高风景建筑摄影技能的高级摄影师，这些技巧都可以显着提高您的拍摄效果。

请记住要注意建筑中垂直方向会聚的问题，并考虑使用移轴镜头。此外，还要注重通过运用对称、三分法和取景等技术来创作强有力的构图。

因此，让我们从绝对基础开始深入研究：

什么是反向镜头宏摄影？

反向镜头宏观摄影是一种使用可互换的镜头相机，镜头和便宜的适配器捕获高度放大图像的方法。您将镜头旋转，以便后部元素向外指向，然后使用适配器将反向镜头连接到相机车身（或其他镜头）。

换句话说：您拿起镜头。你把它翻转。而且您将可以在宏观上拍摄。

如果您从未看过反向镜头宏观技术，那似乎有些奇怪 - 毕竟，为什么逆转标准镜头会让您以高宏伟的形式拍摄？

但这确实可以工作，下图显示了原因。在正常使用中，一个50mm的镜头将光线从远处聚焦，以创建一个较小的图像，该图像适合膜或数字传感器（通常约为35mm宽）。逆转镜头，相反发生：50mm镜头放大了它所看到的，几乎具有生命大小的繁殖：

如何进行反向镜头摄影

您可以通过两种方式使用反向镜头宏技术：

1.单镜头反向宏

此方法涉及将一个镜头反向镜头上的镜头。首先，购买一个类似的倒车环（也称为反向环）：

您可以在亚马逊上以便宜的价格购买这些适配器。一侧像过滤器一样螺丝在镜头的末端，而另一侧则固定在镜头安装座上。这是一个反向的戒指：

请注意，如果您使用带有手动光圈环的镜头，则反向宏技术效果最好。这样，您可以停下来增加清晰度的区域（这非常有用，因为随着您接近对象， 景深会减小）。

不幸的是，如果您的反向镜头没有手动光圈戒指，则您将无法进行任何F-Stop调整，并且您将被迫以镜头的最大光圈工作。但是，尽管这可能不便，但不要让它阻止您 - 您可以使用最宽的光圈使用反向镜头拍摄一些漂亮的照片。您只需要发挥创造力！

2.双镜头反向宏

这种反向镜头宏技术不太受欢迎，但可以完成工作。您没有将一个镜头倒在相机上，而是正常安装一个镜头，然后将第二个镜头安装在第一个镜头上，如这样：

实际的力学几乎与上面讨论的单镜头技术相同。只需购买一个耦合器环（如下所示）。然后使用它将第二个镜头安装到第一个镜头。

现在，当使用双镜头反向宏观技术时，相反的镜头的作用就像是强大的特写滤镜，只是它比我遇到的任何过滤器要强得多。实际上，双镜头技术比单镜头技术提供了两个主要好处：

  1. 它提供了疯狂的关闭宏伟。根据您使用的焦距，您最多可以实现3倍的寿命繁殖。 （那是大多数专业宏观镜头的三倍！）
  2. 它增加了您的景深灵活性。您可以将相反的镜头以最大的光圈打开，同时停止将主要镜头降低以增加景深（即使您没有手动孔径环）。

请注意，您可以使用任何镜头进行此技术，尽管焦距越长，您将获得的放大倍数越多。最重要的是，两个镜头上的滤波器大小匹配 - 这样，您可以购买一个可以轻松将它们连接在一起的耦合器环。

（如果您的镜头有不同的过滤线，则除了您的耦合器环外，您还可以选择购买升级环，但这可能会带来不便。）

照顾反向镜头

反向宏技术确实使您的反向镜头的后部元素打开到元素，无论您使用哪种方法。因此，您应该始终仔细工作，以避免刮擦裸露的元素以及连接引脚。

如果您有扩展管，则可以像上面的照片一样，将其连接到反向镜头的背面（现在）。这有助于保护后元件，并充当镜头罩。此外，如果您还没有准备好射击，请保持镜头上有后镜头盖。

最后，由于镜头的风险，我建议使用相对便宜的玻璃，例如50mm f/1.8 。

图像清晰度

相反的镜头技术使您与主体如此接近，以至于几乎不可能掌握相机。为了获得最明显的结果，请使用三脚架保持相机稳定，并使用电缆释放来发射快门。

我发现最好在室内使用反向镜头宏观设置，尤其是对于花朵等精致的主题。如果您在外面尝试一下，那么微风可以移动花朵并破坏照片。

当然，您始终可以接受模糊的结果并创建一些有趣的抽象照片 - 但是，如果您的目标是创建放大秀的照片，则需要密切关注此建议。

如果可能的话，将主要镜头停止至至少f/4。这样，您将获得增加的景深，如果您使用的是双镜头技术，它将帮助您避免在第一个镜头处于最宽的光圈设置时可能发生的软化。

如何轻倒镜头摄影

只要您不介意使用三脚架和长途快门速度获得所需的曝光，自然光就可以正常工作。

但是，Flash也是一个选择。而且您不需要专门的宏观闪光灯 - 我使用带有小软箱的佳能雪橇（尽管您可能需要确保使用镜头外闪光灯以避免镜头施放的阴影）。

我需要拍摄上面的照片所需的全部闪光灯和软箱。这是设置的图：

您应该使用什么镜头进行反向宏拍摄？

我在本文中使用了50mm Prime镜头为照片。五十五十是从反向镜头宏摄影开始的好方法。

但是，不要忘记，您可以使用几乎所有镜头尝试一下（尽管我建议您使用更便宜的选项，以防万一您的镜头损坏）。 佳能EF-S 18-55mm f/3.5-5.6之类的套件镜头II （如上图所示）很棒。

有一个旧的胶卷镜头吗？

如果您是像我这样的老人，您会记得电影。您甚至可能会有旧的胶卷相机和一些镜头来启动它。如果没有，则胶片摄像头镜头在当地商店，在线甚至车库销售中便宜。对于此技术，镜头品牌或安装型无关紧要，因为您不会以通常的方式将镜头连接到相机。几乎所有镜头都可以工作，只要它在正面上有过滤螺纹即可。

我与旧的Pentax Me Super Film相机一起使用的镜头是50mm Pentax镜头，带有49mm滤清器环和带有72mm滤清器的Vivitar 28-105mm变焦。使用反向镜头时要记住的事情是焦距越宽，您可以越接近主题。变焦镜头可为您提供“可变宏”。

旧电影摄像头镜头最有效的最大原因是，与大多数数字镜头不同，它们在镜头上具有光圈控制环。您将无法控制相机的光圈，因此将其放在镜头上是完美的。

一流的反向镜头宏观照片的其他提示

现在您已经熟悉基础知识，让我们看一些快速的建议，以改善您的倒镜头宏观镜头，从以下方式开始：

1.考虑镜头焦距

通过考虑想要多少放大倍数来选择所需的镜头 - 较短的焦距可以使您更接近主题，而更长的焦距使您可以远离主题，但提供了更少的放大倍率。

当对我的50mm pentax Prime进行逆转时，我能够以1：1的放大率拍照。我的Vivitar 28-105mm的28mm变焦使我接近2：1的比例。但是，在105mm时，它更多的是特写镜头，而不是宏观镜头，而在70mm左右，是1：1。

2.仔细选择您的主题

进行反向安装宏照片时的景深将是薄薄的（有时只有几毫米）。如果您以前从未做过较浅的田野照片深度，则可能需要首先选择具有最小深度的主题并将其定位，使其与相机相同。邮票，硬币，纸张账单或其他平坦物体很棒，尤其是在学习技术时。

3.将相机设置为手动模式

进行反向安装摄影时，您将能够从相机中控制ISO和快门速度，但不能控制光圈。 （请记住，那是在镜头环上。）使用手动模式 - 它允许您独立设置ISO和快门速度 - 将使您可以调整曝光并尝试不同的设置，直到获得所需的结果为止。

我建议您集中精力，然后再拨入曝光设置。为了获得最佳效果，请在手动聚焦时一直打开光圈环。以微小的增量来回移动相机或主题，直到获得所需的焦点为止（焦点戒指不会产生太大的效果）。

一些快速提示：如果您使用的变焦，则可以使用Zoom功能来帮助您进行聚焦。如果您的相机具有实时视图，请使用它。使用实时视图的缩放功能来放大主题并检查焦点。如果您没有实时视图，则必须关注取景器。请记住：自动对焦对这种摄影不起作用，因此，您可以触摸专注的LCD屏幕无济于事。

一旦您专注于镜头，如果镜头有一个光圈环，请使用它。较小的光圈会产生更大的景深，因此，如果您要拍摄一个稍微更深的主题，则需要确保使用一个小的（即狭窄）的光圈。

知道，当您停止镜头时，取景器和整体曝光也会变得更黑。同样，很难在不稍微碰到焦点的情况下调整光圈环，因此请准备根据需要重新聚焦。

反向镜头宏摄影：结论

现在您已经完成了本文，您应该可以自信地创建宏观摄影设置（而不必在专用的宏观镜头上花费很多钱）。

本文于2023年12月更新了梅琳达·史密斯， 拉拉·怀特， 凯文·兰德沃 - 约翰和安妮·陶的贡献。

您是否厌倦了花很长时间来挑选最好的照片？您想知道如何快速选择照片吗？

当我刚开始以摄影师的身份开始时，每次拍摄后，我都会挂在图片选择过程中。我会花太多时间在每张照片上感到痛苦（我非常担心意外丢弃一张好照片……）。

但是随着时间的流逝，我制定了几种策略。策略：

  • 加快了我的工作流程
  • 使淘汰过程减轻了痛苦
  • 帮助我专注于实际的照片编辑

在下面，我分享了其中九种策略，所有这些策略都可以保证将选择图片变成小菜一碟，我也解释了为什么要努力选择最佳镜头如此重要。

让我们开始吧！

1.首先不要拍太多照片

是的，我知道；这并不是几分钟内整理数百张照片的方法。但是对于许多摄影师来说，故意拍摄更少的照片是改变游戏规则的，因此您至少应该考虑。

我明白了： 数字存储价格便宜，相机提供了疯狂的深度缓冲区，因此射击一千张照片感觉很好，知道您最终会得到一些体面的射击。但是，实际上有多少张照片是好的？为了获得一些好的镜头，您真正需要采取多少件事？

根据我的经验，不仅要拍摄这么多镜头，而且实际上是有害的。作为摄影师，如果您的手指始终按下快门按钮，您将变得懒惰。您不会花时间仔细编写图像。取而代之的是，您会拍摄很多，但您也会错过很多，您的照片会遭受损失。

另外，不断拍摄带来了另一个主要缺点：

您必须在图像山上进行排序才能找到最好的图像。

底线：

您无需拍摄数百张图像。而且，如果您可以克制自己，那么在后处理和组织阶段，您将有很多时间。

合理？

2.从最好的开始

在涉及自己的创作方面，创造力的人通常会脱颖而出。您听说音乐家几次告诉您他们的练习不足以表演？还是绘画的朋友告诉您他们没有信心完成他们正在工作的画布？

创意者对自己太努力是很典型的，这可能会减慢淘汰过程的速度，或者更糟糕的是，使您丢弃值得看的图像。

因此，当您第一次从新照片会话中加载图像时，请有意为正面。不要让自己被消极的想法陷入困境。开始寻找您制作的系列中最好的照片，而不是最糟糕的照片。

花一些时间扫描并概述您的新图片。寻找那些激发您并标记它们的人。您可以使用标志，颜色标签或星级等级。虽然这需要一些时间，但它将使其其余的选择过程变得更加容易！

3.选择反映您风格的图像

如果您想对事件进行扎实的叙述，或者想产生一个凝聚力的作品集，那么不要仅仅考虑“好图像”和“坏图像”。

相反，问问自己：

这个图像适合我的风格吗？如果没有，请拒绝它。您不必将镜头扔掉 - 毕竟，您的风格可能会改变，您可能需要像这样的图像 - 但现在将其放在一边，这样您就可以专注于所开发的样式。

例如，如果您的风格涉及黑暗，喜怒无常，戏剧性的图像，那么无论多么出色，明亮，乐观，通风​​的镜头可能都不属于您的投资组合。应该被垃圾吗？可能不是，但很快将其添加到拒绝文件夹中并继续前进。稍后，如果您决定创建一个更快乐的图像组合，您将知道在哪里可以找到它。但是与此同时，将其挡住了，花时间在重要的事情上。

4.寻找干扰

当您选择自己喜欢的图片时，请确保您过度关注，不仅在主要主题上，而且在背景，前景和可能包含的任何干扰。

Distractions are easy to miss when out shooting, but they can seriously detract from an image, so it's up to you, in the editing room, to identify them and send them packing.

I'm talking about things like:

  • Telephone poles
  • 路灯
  • 电线
  • 路人
  • 汽车
  • 栅栏
  • 树木

Really, it all depends on the image – certain items can be distracting in one shot but work well in another – so take the above list with a grain of salt. But make sure you keep an eagle eye out for any and all distractions; that way, you can quickly reject photos that ultimately won't work.

One thing to note, though:

Certain distractions can be fixed in post-processing. For instance, telephone wires can be removed from a portrait, cars can be removed from a street scene, etc. And you must decide whether the distraction is fixable and whether it's actually worth fixing (especially if you took another, similar shot that doesn't suffer from the same issues).

Check out this set of images:

The top image features a garden hose in the grass, but I removed it in post-processing, and the photo looks much better. The image was too good to send it packing, and I knew the hose would be easy to edit out, so I held on to the shot. In the end, it's your call, but don't keep too many images that require major fixes; it's just not worth it.

5. If a shot is out of focus or blurry, reject it

If any photos have softness or blurriness, they're automatically out. That's my rule and I stick to it, no matter what else the photo offers.

After all, if you're shooting for a client and you include a blurry image in their package, what if they want to print it on a huge canvas? An image that appears blurry at low resolutions will look horrible when blown up big, so just don't go there. Instead, get rid of blurriness as soon as you identify it.

It's often possible to instantly tell whether an image is blurry, but if you're not sure, you can zoom in to one hundred percent in your favorite post-processing program, check for focus/blur, and then make your final decision.

(This rule also applies to any photos that are way off with exposure. Just let them go!)

I'll be the first to admit: This can be really tough. Sometimes, the best poses are ruined by blur and I hate to get rid of them, but I know it's necessary. Here's an example where the top photo has the better head turns and expressions, yet one of the faces is blurry:

So I had to go with the bottom image.

6. Eliminate similar shots on your first photo-picking pass

When you're choosing pictures, every time you come to a series of similar shots, be ruthless. Get rid of all but one photo, because no portfolio should include a handful of near-identical images, and no client wants to wade through a bunch of twin images, either.

Even if both photos are amazing, just pick one. You can do this any way you like: flip a coin, always go with the one on the left, or (and this is ideal) pick the one that makes you feel the most, because one of the shots is bound to be better than另一个。 You might also consider checking sharpness, exposure, and thinking about which shot speaks to your style and your client's interests.

When comparing the two shots above, I knew I needed to get rid of one. But which would it be? I went with the image on the right because the expression was slightly more enthusiastic, and that little girl was full of enthusiasm. I wanted to show her personality!

7. Don't miss the hidden gems

Thus far, I've offered strategies for getting down to your best shots as quickly as possible. But I'd like to throw this piece of advice out there:

Sometimes, the best photos aren't immediately visible. Sometimes, it's the hidden gems that include the best expressions, the best moments, the most worthwhile scenes.

So while you should go through your photos fast, if an image speaks to you, don't immediately reject it, even if it has issues. Perhaps the shot could be great with just a little bit of magical editing.

For instance, check out the images below. The top left shot has two great expressions and one bad one. So I took the bad expression, and I replaced it with the expression from another photo:

Just watch for that kind of thing: Photos that could be your favorites after a wave of the magic editing wand.

8. Be ruthless, and don't be afraid to make mistakes

The whole point of this article is to help you pick photos fast , and you can't do that unless you're willing to make mistakes.

Yes, you'll occasionally reject great photos. Yes, you'll occasionally fail to identify shots that could be massively improved with editing. But is that such a bad thing? Why is rejecting a good photo so problematic? It's not like you're truly trashing it. Assuming you have plenty of storage, you can keep it on your hard drive, then come back to it later if the urge arises.

And you've got to be ruthless, too. You can't edit every photo, and sometimes you just have to make quick judgment calls and move on. (On the other hand, as emphasized above, don't be too negative! Accidentally rejecting a good shot or two is okay, but you don't want to fall prey to negative thinking and struggle to find anything that you like!)

With the photos above, the one on the left is cute, but I decided that I liked the connection displayed in the middle shot, so that's the one I kept. Did I make the right decision? I don't know for sure, but I can always return to the other image if I decide it's superior.

Quick tip: If I'm having a really hard time giving photos up, I will give them star ratings as I go through: five stars for definite keepers and four stars for the “maybes.” I usually end up with more five star shots than I need, so the four stars automatically get cut. Sometimes, it's easier to let images go after you've given them a fair trial.

9. Think about the clients

The business of photography is a complicated matter. I spend hours after each photo shoot culling, processing, and sorting the photos to tell the story of the day.

Now, many photographers are not shooting for clients – and if that's you, you can ignore this section completely! However, if you do photograph for clients, it's important to not just think about what you like, but also what the client likes.

After a recent photo session with one of my children, I realized that choosing the final photos can be described as a Venn diagram ! One circle represents images photographers love and the other circle represents images clients love. Some images overlap and some don't.

To be successful, you want the largest area to be the one that overlaps: images both photographers and clients love.

Sometimes, you'll like an image but you know a client won't like it – perhaps it's a little too artistic or abstract. In such cases, remember the client, and avoid including it in the final portfolio (unless you're confident they'll enjoy a more creative image or two!).

Other times, you know that a client will appreciate an image, even though it's technically imperfect. In such cases, include it in the file selection. At the end of the day, your goal is to please the client, after all!

Why is it important to pick your best images?

Everyone looks at their work and thinks about what they like and don't like. But until you make an actual decision about each image – is it the very best image, is it good (but not great), or is it just a practice shot? – you won't open yourself up to the learning that comes when you actively force yourself to separate the best from the throwaways.

By making decisions about what works and what doesn't, you begin to train your eye. Let's say you are looking at a dozen good images of a landscape, each one slightly different. By comparing and contrasting several good photos, you'll start to realize that some are better, some are worse, and one image is going to be the best.

Which one is the best, and how do you know? With this question in mind, you'll be forced to look at the little details in a new way. Maybe one has better exposure or slightly better composition. The value might be in the details, and you'll have to look carefully, but that's where you'll often find the greatness, and it's often what separates the good photographers from the best photographers!

If you spend time carefully choosing your best shots, you'll begin to see when you nailed the frame and what led to that moment. You'll see what worked in that image, and you'll see what didn't work in the surrounding photos – was there too much sky? Not enough sky? Next time, you'll compose a little bit better. You'll remember what you liked. You'll spend a little less time creating images that you know won't work, and you'll start spending more time creating better images.

Choosing your best photos: final words

I hope this article has given you some photo-picking strategies you can use the next time you need to go through lots of photos in a short amount of time.

Just remember: It's okay to make mistakes. And don't be afraid to get ruthless! It'll make things far easier.

什么是光圈优先模式？你应该在摄影中使用它吗？如何使用光圈优先来捕捉曝光良好的艺术图像？

In this guide, I explain everything you need to know about Aperture Priority, including:

  • When it's useful (and when it should be avoided)
  • The difference between Aperture Priority and other common camera modes (such as Shutter Priority)
  • How to adjust your camera settings while using Aperture Priority
  • How to handle common Aperture Priority mode scenarios

So if you're ready to take control of your camera and become a settings master , then let's dive right in!

什么是光圈优先模式？

Aperture Priority mode, often represented as “A” or “Av” mode, gives the photographer control over the aperture and the ISO , while the camera selects a corresponding shutter speed .

In other words, you get to determine your ideal aperture and ISO based on artistic and image-quality concerns. And then your camera will choose the shutter speed that produces a well-exposed , detailed image.

Aperture Priority is a semi-automatic camera mode. It doesn't offer full control over camera variables, but it does let you adjust several key settings (ie, aperture and ISO). It's designed to provide both flexibility and speed; that way, you can focus on the subject, composition, and artistry while the camera optimizes the exposure.

Aperture Priority mode variables: aperture, shutter speed, and ISO

If you set your camera to Aperture Priority mode, you immediately gain control over the aperture and ISO while your camera takes control of the shutter speed – but what do these different settings offer, and why do they matter?

Together, aperture, shutter speed, and ISO are part of the exposure triangle . By adjusting any of the three variables, you consequently adjust the exposure (ie, brightness) of the resulting image. However, when you use Aperture Priority mode, your camera automatically compensates for aperture and ISO adjustments by changing the shutter speed (with the goal of creating a spot-on exposure).

So if you widen the aperture, your camera will increase the shutter speed to compensate for the brighter exposure. And if you drop the ISO, your camera will decrease the shutter speed to compensate for the darker exposure.合理？

Here's the bottom line: When using Aperture Priority, your camera will always try to maintain a good exposure, even as you adjust the aperture and ISO.

But you might be wondering: If the aperture and ISO don't adjust the exposure, then why would I want to change the aperture? Why would I want to change the ISO? What do those two settings offer me?

Aperture and ISO produce three key effects:

  1. By widening or narrowing the aperture, you can adjust the depth of field (that is, the amount of the image that's in focus). A wide aperture (eg, f/1.8) creates a very thin plane of focus, so most of the image blurs away. And a narrow aperture (eg, f/16) creates a very deep plane of focus, so the entire scene remains sharp.
  2. By increasing or decreasing the ISO, you can adjust the level of noise in the image. Noise appears as tiny specks of color and light, and it obscures image detail – so by keeping the ISO low, you can maximize image quality.
  3. By adjusting the aperture or ISO, you can force the camera to change the shutter speed. A fast shutter speed is essential for capturing action scenes (eg, birds in flight or basketball players on the move), and by widening the aperture and/or raising the ISO, you make the camera boost the shutter speed. A slow shutter speed is essential for capturing beautiful long-exposure effects , and by narrowing the aperture and/or lowering the ISO, you make the camera drop the shutter speed.

So by adjusting settings in Aperture Priority mode, you can improve image quality, add beautiful depth of field effects, and even create some long-exposure artistry.

The fourth variable: exposure compensation

As I emphasized above, Aperture Priority mode tells your camera to set the exposure (by adjusting the shutter speed) while you handle other image variables. And in general, the camera will do a good job and you'll get nice, detailed exposures.

But camera exposure meters aren't perfect, and there are times when you should deliberately overexpose or underexpose your images (often when photographing very light scenes and very dark scenes, respectively).

Now, you cannot adjust the exposure by changing the aperture, ISO, or shutter speed. In Aperture Priority mode, the shutter speed setting is locked – and a change in the aperture and ISO settings will be automatically counteracted by a change in the shutter speed.

That's why cameras offer another setting, called exposure compensation . Exposure compensation is generally represented by plus (+) and minus (-) symbols, and it lets you instruct your camera to increase or decrease the shutter speed for a brighter or darker effect.

In most cases, you won't need exposure compensation. But if you find yourself wanting to adjust the exposure, don't be afraid to use it!

Aperture Priority mode vs Shutter Priority mode

Aperture Priority offers control over the aperture and ISO, while your camera takes care of adjusting the shutter speed. It's a great tool if you need to control the depth of field in your images.

Shutter Priority , on the other hand, lets you adjust the shutter speed and ISO. Your camera then selects a corresponding aperture for a proper exposure. This mode is especially useful if you're dealing with fast-moving subjects.

Comparing the two, you'll find that Aperture Priority is generally more popular. Many photographers appreciate the ability to manipulate the appearance of sharpness and blurriness in the background.

But Shutter Priority has its fans too, especially among those photographing sports or other high-speed activities. The mode allows for precise control of motion so you can capture every exciting detail or even introduce intentional blur.

However, when you need to control the overall composition with regard to both depth of field and motion, you might find Aperture Priority more appealing. Shutter Priority can be indispensable in some situations, but Aperture Priority often offers greater creative freedom.

Aperture Priority mode vs Manual mode

Manual mode takes things a step further by offering complete control over every camera setting, including shutter speed, aperture, and ISO. It's a powerful way to ensure you get the exact exposure results you desire.

This complete control comes at the cost of speed, however. Adjusting all these variables manually means that Manual mode is often slower to use. It's ideal for scenarios where you can work very deliberately, such as landscapes or studio settings.

Note that, compared to Manual mode, Aperture Priority provides a quick way to adapt to changes in lighting conditions or subject movement. The automatic adjustments your camera makes to the shutter speed can be especially invaluable when time is of the essence.

In scenarios where the light is changing rapidly or subjects are moving from shadow to sunlight and back, Aperture Priority mode offers the speed needed to capture the moment. Manual mode, while unmatched in control, may not be the best choice in these dynamic situations.

In the end, your choice between Aperture Priority and Manual mode will likely depend on the specific demands of the scene and your personal preferences as a photographer. Aperture Priority offers speed and some control, while Manual mode provides the opportunity to fine-tune every aspect of your image. Both modes have unique advantages and applications, so understanding their differences will help you select the right tool for your creative vision.

When should you use Aperture Priority mode?

First of all, Aperture Priority is a great mode to use if you're a beginner hoping to better understand your camera settings. Because your camera will automatically select the shutter speed, you don't have to worry about messing up the exposure – but at the same time, you can experiment with different apertures and see how your images change.

Plus, as you gain in skill, you can start to use the aperture to deliberately adjust the shutter speed and use the exposure compensation function to improve image detail.

但光圈优先模式在已经掌握了相机设置的专业人士中也很受欢迎。 For one, if you don't need to think about the shutter speed but you do care about the aperture, Aperture Priority will focus your attention on the settings that matter (and let you forget about the less-important shutter speed setting). If you're conducting a portrait photoshoot in good light, for instance, Aperture Priority will let you adjust the depth of field without distraction.

Additionally, Aperture Priority, unlike full Manual mode, helps you react to lighting changes. For instance, if your subject moves from a shaded area to a sunny area or if the sun comes out from behind a cloud, Aperture Priority will automatically adjust the shutter speed to compensate for the sudden burst of light.

In certain slower genres of photography, such as landscape photography, this isn't especially helpful – but if you're shooting action, reacting quickly to lighting changes is essential, and Aperture Priority can make a huge difference.

Here are a few genres where Aperture Priority is popular:

  • 人像摄影
  • Bird photography
  • 野生动物摄影
  • 微距摄影
  • 街头摄影

Of course, there is no single best camera mode for a genre, and you can always find photographers who work differently – but the above list is a great starting point.

When should you avoid using Aperture Priority mode?

There are a lot of common mistakes to make in photography, but possibly the most frequent is to shoot in Aperture Priority mode when it's not the best choice.

I see this problem most often when people are traveling. They will stick their camera on Aperture Priority for the entire day, forgetting that the light sometimes will not be strong enough to yield a sufficiently fast shutter speed, particularly if their lens aperture does not widen beyond f/4 or f/3.5.结果？ They come home and many of their images are blurry – when they didn't have to be.

The shutter speed is your first line of defense for creating a sharp image. A good rule of thumb is that the shutter speed should be at least one over the focal length of the lens to offset handheld camera shake. I like to add a little extra speed to be safe, so if you are shooting at 50mm on a full-frame camera, I would aim to keep the shutter speed at 1/80s or faster. And with a crop-sensor camera, a 50mm lens might give you an 80mm equivalent, so I would shoot at least at 1/100s of a second.

Especially if you are using a longer focal length, your shutter speed can go below this threshold very, very easily when you're using Aperture Priority and you aren't shooting in strong, direct light.

Now, you might be saying that you can shoot in Aperture Priority mode (or Manual mode) all of the time – you just have to pay attention to the corresponding shutter speeds so you never have a problem. That's great, and in that case, please keep shooting in Aperture Priority. I don't want to stop you from shooting in a way that works well for you. If you know your camera settings well, then yes, you can effectively shoot in any situation with any of these modes.

However, I teach a good amount of students, and I would guess that about 80 percent of them come in shooting in Aperture Priority. When I take a look at their photos, I notice that – for a good portion of these students – way too many files turn out blurry or have some sharpness issues.

You see, they'll pay attention to their aperture but then zoom for a shot and not notice that the shutter speed is suddenly lower than their focal length, or they won't notice that their shutter speed is too slow to freeze the motion of课程。 I find that switching them over to Shutter Priority for these situations puts the shutter speed at the forefront of their mind. From there, they can pay attention to the corresponding aperture and how they can achieve the deepest possible depth of field.

Particularly for travel photography in cities or areas with people, when I encourage students to try photographing in Shutter Priority at around 1/320s and a higher ISO, they quickly comment on how much sharper their photos become. Give it a try and see if yours improve, too.

How to use Aperture Priority mode: step by step

Working with Aperture Priority mode is simple.

For most cameras, to put your camera on Aperture Priority mode, you need to turn the main mode dial to A (Av for Canon).

When you look at the screen on your camera, you'll notice a number with an F beside it. This is your aperture value. Use the scroller on your camera to change that number. Experiment and see how high and how low you can make that number go.

Then select an aperture based on depth of field considerations. In other words, if you want a deep depth of field, choose a narrow aperture, and if you want a shallow depth of field , choose a wide aperture.

Next, set your preferred ISO (generally the lowest setting your camera offers).

Then check your shutter speed. Is it fast enough for your subject? If you're photographing sports, birds in flight, cars, etc., and you need a faster shutter speed, boost your ISO or widen your aperture.

And if you're photographing moving water, moving clouds, or other moving subjects you wish to blur artistically, consider dropping your ISO or narrowing your aperture to decrease the shutter speed.

Finally, take a test shot and carefully observe the results. If everything looks good – including the exposure – then go ahead and keep shooting.

On the other hand, if your test image looks over- or underexposed, dial in a bit of exposure compensation, and only then begin photographing in earnest.

Handling common Aperture Priority scenarios

In this section, I examine some frequent situations where Aperture Priority mode can be helpful, and I share some settings advice.

人像摄影

Aperture Priority mode is great for portrait photography because it lets you think about the depth of field while your camera handles the exposure.

Most portrait photos look great with a shallow depth of field effect – where the subject is sharp but the background is beautifully blurry:

Simply select a low ISO (such as ISO 100), then dial in a wide aperture. An f/2.8 aperture is a good place to start, but if your lens offers an f/1.8 or f/1.4 maximum aperture, don't be afraid to widen the setting further.

街头摄影

If you're photographing on the streets of a busy city with a mix of sun and shade, Aperture Priority mode is your friend.

Choose a relatively narrow aperture, such as f/8, to keep most of the scene in focus. Then raise the ISO until you have a reasonable shutter speed setting in the shade (1/250s is a good minimum speed to shoot for!).

That way, as you and your subjects move in and out of the shadows, your camera will make sure the exposure remains balanced!

Action photography

If you're shooting sports players or other fast-moving subjects, simply dial in a relatively wide aperture (such as f/4 or f/5.6).

Pick an ISO that gives you a fast shutter speed (for many action subjects, 1/1000s is a good starting point).

Then, as the sun moves behind clouds, your camera will automatically adjust the shutter speed to compensate for the loss of light, and you'll end up with beautiful images.

微距摄影

Aperture Priority is a great way to capture stunning macro photos; by controlling the aperture, you can create a beautiful shallow depth of field effect!

Get in close and dial in a wide aperture setting. This allows you to focus on intricate details, such as the texture of flower petals or the eye of an insect, and it'll create a stunning blur in the background that highlights the main subject.

Experimenting with different apertures will let you see how the depth of field changes. Don't be afraid to test various settings to achieve the effect you desire.

It's a hands-on process that can provide incredible results. Whether you're capturing the delicate wings of a butterfly or the intricate patterns of a leaf, Aperture Priority offers the flexibility to make it happen.

Wildlife and bird photography

Wildlife and bird photography require a balance of precision and speed. Aperture Priority mode allows you to select a reasonably wide aperture, but not so wide that your subjects will only be partially in focus.

Choosing the right aperture is the first step. You can then check the selected shutter speed and adjust it as needed by raising or lowering the ISO. This method allows for quick adjustments as your subjects move.

Remember: Wildlife photography often involves unpredictable movements. A bird might suddenly take flight, or an animal might dart from sun to shade.

In these dynamic scenarios, Aperture Priority helps you maintain focus on the subject while still allowing for adjustments to capture the action. This blend of control and adaptability is why many photographers opt for Aperture Priority when out in the wild!

Aperture Priority mode: final words

Aperture Priority is a powerful camera mode, one that's great for both professionals and beginners.

So try out Aperture Priority. Practice adjusting your settings. I'm betting you'll like the results!

But while mountains look amazing, capturing amazing shots of mountains – the kind that do justice to their grandeur and power – can be tough. Fortunately, you're not on your own!

Below, we share plenty of advice to elevate your mountain photography from zero to hero, including my thoughts on gear, weather, lighting, and so much more. We also delve into mountain lake photography – so that you can combine two of nature's most gorgeous elements to produce pro-level landscape photos .

And since each tip comes from direct experience in the field, you can be confident that it's worth your time!

Ready to get better results the next time you go chasing after mountains?让我们开始吧。

1. Take advantage of the light

Lighting may be the single most important aspect of a successful mountain photo. While backlight and front light can work under some circumstances, mountains thrive in sidelight. Light from the side brings out the shadows and details in ridges, cliffs, and rolling slopes. It provides contrast and drama.

Images of big landscapes, like mountains, rely on natural light for illumination, so you're really at the whim of the weather. Cloudy days can flatten the light, while midday sun will drown out shadows and turn pleasing contrast into an eye-squinting mass of whites and blacks. Successful images can arise from these challenging scenarios, but low-angle sidelight – that is, golden-hour landscape lighting – makes our lives as photographers so much easier.

2. Place your horizon carefully

Your horizon is one of the most important parts of the photo. Think about the rule of thirds and – unless you have a very good reason to do so! – avoid putting your horizon in the middle of the frame.

If the scene has an interesting foreground and/or an uninteresting sky (ie, white clouds or a pure, flat blue) place your horizon line high in the frame.

Alternatively, if you're faced with interesting cloud formations and/or a relatively featureless foreground, you could place your horizon line lower to show more of the sky.

3. Fill the frame

Mountains, by nature, are huge. You don't have to get the entire thing in the frame. It's just as acceptable to fill the frame with a certain element that draws your attention. This will make the mountain the background in your images.

Yes, it can be tempting to try and get a huge vista in the frame. But if you take a moment to look for smaller details that could make an interesting photo, you might find something unexpected.

4. Show scale with smaller elements

Again, mountains tend to be huge, but when you shoot with an ultra-wide-angle lens , you wind up pushing the perspective back. And this makes it difficult to give your viewers a true sense of just how large things are within your frame.

You can combat this by including an element that shows the scale of things in the scene. Buildings, people, and animals all work well.

5. Include people in the landscape

As with the previous point, putting people in your mountain landscape photography can convey just how big the mountains are.

It does more than that, however! By including a human element, you are adding something that your viewers can relate to.

6. Don't forget about color

Bright colors attract the eye. This is particularly true in images of mountains. Sunset and sunrise, colorful foregrounds, and bright blue alpine skies will help catch and hold the gaze of a viewer.

This goes very tidily with the very first mountain photography tip (on using the light!). Good light very often equates to good color. The better the light quality, the more vivid the colors of the scene become. Get one and you often get the other.

None of this is to say that an image has to have bright colors to be successful. Low-saturation images can be moody and brooding. Stormy skies and winter scenes are two examples where colors may not be rich but don't hurt the final image. Such photos thrive on the drama of the scene rather than the colors.

In black-and-white images, color is completely absent but can depict the mountains beautifully . In such images, contrast and mood play an even more important role.

A note on black-and-white mountain photography: when factors like light and color are not in your favor, a black-and-white conversion can often be a great tool. I've made numerous images on flat-light days that converted well to black and white, though the color image was dull and muted.

7. Try a panorama

When you are photographing mountains, don't be afraid to take a sequence of shots that you can stitch together as a panorama .

Mountain ranges tend to suit the panorama format especially well because there is just so much to see!

8. Fill your foreground

This may be standard landscape photography advice, but it still applies when shooting mountains. If you're using a wide-angle lens, you will have plenty of space in your foreground – and you'll need to fill it with something interesting.

So pick a foreground subject and get up close to it. This could be flowers, an interesting rock formation, or something simple like a sign.

Then take a shot that combines the interesting foreground and a beautiful mountain background, like this:

9. Include a human element

By human element , I don't mean people. Instead, I advise you to find something human-made that will show your viewers how the people that live nearby incorporate the mountain into their lives.

On their own, mountains are impressive. But as part of our world, they are also part of our lives. If you can show this in your images, you might be able to convey an interesting narrative.

10. Try juxtaposition

Juxtaposition refers to contrasting elements placed in relation to one another. In photography, that contrast can be visual – light versus dark contrast, bright versus muted colors, warm versus cool colors – as well conceptual, in terms of contrasting subject matter.

And in my experience, all of these are important parts of mountain photography!

Juxtaposed color tones combine in interesting ways. Mountain scenes, particularly from places like the Rockies, Cascades, or Alaska, tend to be dominated by cool tones: blue skies, green tundra and forest, glacial streams, and clear blue lakes. These cool-colored scenes often look better when warm tones, like yellow, red, or pink, are integrated into the scene. Often that warm tone is best presented as a flash of color – a setting sun, a wildflower, or the bright jacket of a hiker – rather than as an equal to the cool tones.

(When both cool and warm tones are heavily featured in a scene, your brain will have a hard time sorting out which to pay attention to and the pleasing juxtaposition will become a tangle of clashing color.)

For me, though, subject juxtaposition is where a landscape image comes alive. When it comes to mountains, there is so much potential for subject-based contrast.

Some contrasting mountain shots, like the image below of the rainbow over the desert mountains of Big Bend National Park, have obvious subject juxtapositions (rain versus the dry desert rock). But the same image also has visual contrasts in shapes and texture (the jagged rocks and smooth curve of the rainbow, for example). All of these combine nicely to provide interest.

11. Use a different focal point

In your mountain landscape photography, the mountain does not need to be the focal point of your image. Instead, you can find a different focal point and use the mountain as environmental information.

Of course, you can still take a photograph of the sweeping vista. But once that is done, look smaller – and see if there are other subjects to be found in the scene.

12. Incorporate mountain lakes

There's something incredibly alluring about lake and river reflections in landscape photography, especially when surrounded by majestic snow-capped mountains that glow hot from the light of the setting sun. So whenever you can, try to include a mountain lake – with a gorgeous reflection – in your shots!

A few quick tips for amazing mountain lake photography:

Wait for the wind to stop

If you're out on a gale-force windy day, don't expect any serene lake shots. You need that water to be perfectly still for good reflections. A mild, occasional wind is fine, just stick around and wait for it to die down. You only need a few minutes. Bring a camp chair and thermos, then sit while you wait for the perfect moment. It'll come.

Use a polarizer (and shoot two versions)

If you shoot lake scenes without a polarizer you'll get a lovely mirror-like reflection, but you might be missing out on some interesting details under the water in the foreground. I like to take at least two shots with my polarizer in different positions. One shot will give me the maximum reflection, while the other shot will reduce that reflection to reveal the details under the water. I can then easily blend the two exposures in Photoshop to get the best mixture of reflection and water detail.

Adjust your angle

I like to pick the most interesting point of my mountain range, and then find a spot in my foreground that reflects that interesting point. I often need to get the camera down closer to the ground to achieve this, sometimes adjusting the tripod to its lowest point. At times, though, you might not need to get so low and maybe just step back a few feet to place your reflection where you need it to be.

You can't change where the mountain is, but you can change your position relative to it to capture an interesting foreground and reflection.

Star reflections are incredible

If you're shooting on a calm, clear night, then you get the chance to capture the Milky Way or star trails in your lake reflection. Place a colossal mountain range in the center of that, and you've got yourself a killer shot!

13. Use your GND filters

To help you get good exposure while in the field, don't forget to pack your graduated neutral density filters . These will allow you to even out your exposures at the time of capture, making it easier to process your images when you get back home.

14. Shoot from different angles

When you're just starting out with mountain photography, it's easy to get stuck in the habit of shooting from the same perspective over and over again – but whenever possible, I encourage you to mix it up!

While you can photograph mountains from an infinite number of angles and perspectives, I'd like to focus on three broad approaches: low-angle, mid-mountain, and high-angle shooting. Note that each of these greatly impacts not just the appearance of the final image but also its mood and feel.

Photographs made from a valley bottom looking up will make the mountains appear large and imposing. These low-angle shots provide space for an interesting foreground, and many classic landscapes have been captured from this perspective. Though effective, there are drawbacks to shooting from the valley bottom. The low perspective means that the view is limited; there are no seas of mountain peaks spreading to the horizon. Lighting is often difficult. The bottom of the valley is the last place to gain sunlight in the morning and the first to lose it in the evening, so balancing that light can make the exposure tricky. By the time the landscape is evenly lit, the sweet light of dawn or dusk will be long past.

Mid-mountain shots can be spectacular, providing views both below and above. This perspective is one of my favorites, allowing for a lot of depth in the landscape while maintaining the size and drama of the mountains.

However, capturing great high-angle mountain photos is tough. Images made from the summit of peaks tend to make the surrounding landscape look small. I've taken photographs from peaks in which all the mountains look like rocky waves rather than towering summits. You can make up for this by adding a human to the shot , which provides scale, plus it removes the focus from the mountains and places it on the human experience within them. The human element will change your image, making it less of a landscape and more of a portrait or action shot, but the approach can be very effective.

15. Wait for the light

This tip cannot be understated. If you want the best-looking mountain landscape photography images that you can produce, wait for the light to be at its best. If you get on location early and find the composition that you want, don't be afraid to stay until the light shifts – even if it takes a couple of hours.

Yes, I know it can seem boring, and it's hard to justify the effort, but please, trust me. It is very much worth the time and effort.

16. Use longer lenses

When you are packing for your trip into the mountains, don't forget to take your longer lenses with you. Standard-length primes can be great for panoramas, but telephoto lenses can help you pick out smaller details in your scenes.

换句话说：

There is a lot of room in landscape photography for lenses aside from the wide angles that dominate the genre.

17. Plan for the light

With the technology available to us , it's easier than ever to know exactly which direction the light is going to come from on any given day of the year.

So once you know when and where you are going, do your research and figure out where the sun is going to rise or set. Then plan your shots based on that!

18. Plan for the weather

Like planning for the light, it's also a good idea to plan for the weather. Knowing the weather will help you determine if you need to pack any extra gear like rain covers and waterproof clothing.

Of course, it's also in the best interest of personal safety to have an idea of when snow or rain might appear. This is even more important if you intend to be on the mountain, especially after golden hour.

19. Don't avoid bad weather

While planning for bad weather is good, you don't always need to stay indoors. Many times, the most interesting photos will come in the worst weather.

In fact, some of the best light I have ever seen has been during a break in a storm; these breaks allow just enough light to make things look like a fairytale.

And if you lock yourself away when the weather is bad, you'll never get to experience such moments.

20. Be safe

Above all, strive for safety. Mountain landscape photography can be incredibly rewarding, but don't risk your personal well-being for a great shot.

Watch where you're going, take weather-appropriate clothing, be aware of the forecast, and tell somebody where you are going to be. And if you're going to stay out until after blue hour, make sure you know exactly how to get back.

Mountain landscape photography: final words

I hope this article has inspired you to get out and create your own mountain photography.

The next time you're out shooting mountains, remember these tips – and have fun!

Have you photographed mountains before? Do you have any tips of your own? Share them in the comments below!

Mountain photography FAQ

What type of lens is best for mountain photography?

All lenses have their uses. Wide-angle lenses are the most popular, but standard and telephoto lenses can work, too.

What's the best time of day to photograph mountains?

It entirely depends on where the light is hitting the mountain. The golden hours are best as long as the sun isn't behind your mountain.

How do you show how big a mountain is in a photograph?

You include an element that is easy for the viewer to identify, such as a person. This will give your images a sense of scale.

Why do the mountains in my photographs look so far away?

Wide-angle lenses distort perspective, and this can push everything back in the frame. Use a standard focal length (35mm to 50mm) for a perspective close to the human eye's. To include more in the frame, consider shooting in a panoramic format.

Street portrait photography is incredibly fun and rewarding, but it's not always easy to capture a great image. You might struggle to find the right subjects and the right compositions – or you might feel uncomfortable photographing people as you pass them in the streets.

I love taking street portraits, and in this article, I share all of my favorite tips and techniques for beautiful results. I explain how to work with different backgrounds, how to capture interesting poses, and how to approach people so you can capture a quick shot. By the time you're done, you'll be ready to create interesting and evocative images of your very own.

So whether you're a street portrait beginner or you simply want to level up your existing skills, read on!

What is a street portrait?

A street portrait shows the person's face. It can be captured with permission, but it doesn't have to be. And, of course, it's taken on the street.

There is an authentic element to street portraiture. You're not taking a model out with you, and if you do ask for permission, you never know whether the person you ask will agree to let you take their photo.

Of course, if you are granted permission, you'll be able to control many elements of the shot. You might be able to ask your subject to stand in front of an interesting background, turn their face toward a light source, or control their facial expression.

But how do you create outstanding street portraits? Here are plenty of tips and techniques to help you out:

1. Keep your photos simple

When it comes to street portraits, simplicity is your friend . Aim for simple subjects, simple backgrounds, and simple compositions.

So before pressing the shutter button, carefully observe the scene. Are there unnecessary elements? Is the background simple enough to emphasize the subject? Does the entire shot feel balanced and uncluttered?

If you do notice unnecessary parts of a composition, try to remove them. Sometimes, this is as simple as moving a few steps to the right or the left. Other times, you may need to get close, move farther away, or get up high.

Pro tip: One of the quickest ways to ruin a street portrait is by including a busy, complex background. A busy background will make your image look flat, it will swallow up your subject, and it'll distract the viewer's eye. Personally, I love backgrounds that are clean, colorful, and strong, like this:

The line in the middle nicely balances the subject, plus the strength of the colors and line contrasts nicely with the older man.

2. Always carry your camera and lens

For the best street portraits, you should always have your camera with you. Don't lug your whole photo bag or a tripod around like a tourist in your own town, of course; just have your camera body and one lens handy, even if you're just heading out for a quick walk or to grab something from the grocery store. I can say from personal experience that it sucks walking the streets, seeing something awesome, and not having your camera with you!

Having a good but compact lens makes a huge impact, too! I like the 50mm f/1.4 or f/1.8 and the 85mm f/1.8, which are both small and relatively lightweight.

Additionally, the wide aperture on these lenses can isolate your subject nicely with a shallow depth of field effect.

3. Know your camera (and choose the right settings)

Knowing your camera, especially its basic operations, is vital to capturing candid street portraits. It takes frequent and focused practice. If you rarely use your camera, it's harder to work with it fluidly.

Choose settings you're comfortable with. Aperture Priority is often popular because, with street portraits, it's important to control your exposure and depth of field. With Aperture Priority mode, you can select an aperture for a nice depth of field effect, then you can keep an eye on your shutter speed and make overall settings adjustments as needed.

Now, Aperture Priority will allow you to take pictures quickly. The downside is that you're restricted to whatever exposure the camera chooses unless you use exposure compensation. But this can slow you down as you may not have compensation applied when you most need it.

Therefore, it can also be a good idea to master your camera's Manual mode. Learning manual mode allows you to have tighter control of your exposures and to know at a glance exactly what settings you're working with. Yes, it takes more practice. But unless you practice, you'll never know the advantages you have when you're in control.

Whatever mode you use, be confident with it. Being able to use your camera without having to think allows you to engage more with your environment, which is particularly important when you're making portraits.

4. Think about the light and shadows

Street portrait lighting matters! Even if you capture a great subject at a great moment, if the lighting doesn't work, the entire shot will be ruined. I have a few tips to help you out:

First, avoid using the built-in flash on your camera. This is a common mistake made by beginners. For me, the built-in flash is only for quick shots of friends or family. If you want to capture a street portrait with great light, use natural light, not flash!

Second, try to avoid shooting under heavy sun. The reason is simple: hard light means hard shadows! Normally, when you take a portrait in the sun, it creates hard shadows under the eyes, which is (often) a bad look. (If you're already out with your camera and the sun is beaming down from above, you can still capture street portraits – but you might consider asking your subject to move into the shade.)

Third, it's not enough to shoot in good light. You also need to consider how the light and the shadows fall on the subject's face. I like to take a test shot, and then review it on my LCD, paying careful attention to the highlights and the shadows.

5. Break the world into elements

Composition is a fundamental part of street portrait photography, but it's often a sticking point for beginners. After all, how do you arrange the elements of a scene for that perfect amount of dynamism and balance?

我的建议？ Try to break down the world into elements. Then tell yourself that you're simply organizing the world in an interesting way .

See, 3D eyes and brains make things unnecessarily complex, and – as I discussed in the previous tip – the best street portraits tend to be simple. So you need to see the world simply, too.

You might break down the world into objects (eg, roads, windows, doors, bricks, roofs, people, etc.). Or you might go even further and view the world in terms of geometry (eg, squares, circles, rectangles, and so on). Either can work; the key is to pick a method and stick with it.

Then build your composition from there. Look for relationships among the different elements. Consider ways they can balance out one another across the frame. Remember: You only need one or two interesting elements to make a photo. If you can identify the right elements, and you can put them together in the right way, you'll end up with a beautiful image.

6. Photograph character, not beauty

It may be tempting to look for beautiful or handsome people to photograph. And who could blame you? But you'll create more interesting street portraits full of character if you find interesting people. This means people of both genders and all ages (except children, see the next point).

For example, I captured the photo below in the town of San Antonio de Areco in Argentina. This town is famous for its atmospheric bars and gauchos. While taking photos in one of the bars, somebody told me there was an elderly couple down the road who loved talking to people and having their photo taken. We went to check out the situation and found the couple sitting out on the street. We had an interesting conversation, and I made this portrait:

This also shows how you should be open to opportunities. If people are friendly and make suggestions like this, go with the flow and see where it takes you. Interesting things often happen that way!

7. Use a slow, contemplative approach

When you first start shooting street portraits, it can be a scary experience. You might find yourself rushing in an attempt to prevent tension between yourself and your subject.

But here's the problem:

The best street photography requires contemplation . You need to take a proper look at your subject – especially their eyes, which tell you how the subject is feeling and even thinking.

So do what you can to relax into the experience.慢慢来。 If you need to, use your camera as a sort of shield between yourself and your subject; that way, you feel less tension, and you can spend time observing your subject's face and understanding how they really feel.

If you're just starting out, you can ease into this approach. First, simply look through your camera without firing the shutter. Then once you feel comfortable looking, take an image. Over time, you'll gain confidence, and you'll be able to see a subject and capture a photo in a single instant.

8. Observe and anticipate

Grabbing the action as it happens requires a tight combination of skill and good luck. Anticipating potential action before it happens can often mean you get more consistently good photographs.

I prefer to find a location where I'm comfortable – that is, I'm not in anyone's way and not in the hot sun. I like to make sure that I have a good angle to capture the action as it happens, too.

Knowing the location helps a lot. Being aware of the flow of life in any particular place will help you anticipate when and where you might get the best photos.

Traveling often brings you to different and unfamiliar places. Learning to stop and observe before you photograph will give you a useful sense of the place.

You can also capture street portraits in your own neighborhood, where you're more familiar with the pace of life and the feel of the streets. But it still doesn't hurt to pause and pay attention. Look at what's happening and see the patterns and repeating elements.

Find a balance between planning and spontaneity.做好准备。 Over-planning can kill the natural feel. You don't want to be creating overly contrived street photos. There are already plenty of those on the internet!

9. Look for weird or humorous situations

Some of the best street portraits show the viewer something unexpected or even humorous. It's one of the simplest ways to get started capturing meaningful street photos – plus, when you're out shooting, it'll give you some direction and keep you aware of your surroundings.

For instance, you might look for people making unusual gestures or expressions:

Or you might capture subjects that offer an interesting juxtaposition with background elements:

Note that your images don't need to be eye-popping odd or laugh-out-loud funny. Just train yourself to notice interesting or confusing behavior – and as soon as it happens, raise the camera to your eye and take a photo. Some of the shots will work and others won't.没关系！ With practice, you'll refine your style. In the meantime, have fun experimenting!

10. Find a great background and wait

There is a simple technique among serious street photographers:

You find an interesting location, such as a colorful background, an eye-catching display, or even a sign. Then you wait for someone to walk in front. If you pick an area with significant foot traffic, the right person will meander on through, and you'll get your street portrait – one that combines a stunning background and an interesting subject.

Plus, when you continually gaze at one area for many long minutes, you become very familiar with it. You notice things that you didn't initially see, and you start to understand what makes the location special. You may even decide to come back a second or third or tenth time – in different conditions, under different lighting , using different compositions.

Of course, this technique does require patience, which is a very good thing for a street shooter to develop (and something that beginners often lack). If you find yourself struggling to stay in one place for more than a few seconds, remind yourself that a good scene will appear; you just have to be ready when it does!

11. Make use of color

Some street portraitists prefer to shoot in black and white – but personally, I have always liked shooting in color . Color allows you to communicate different feelings, and you can use it to move the viewer, just the same as you can move them with light or interesting subjects.

So as you walk with your camera, look for color. Notice colorful backgrounds, notice the color of subjects' clothing, notice the color of the shopping bags in their hands. And when you find pairs of colors that seem to work well together, take a photo!

You can also approach color street portraits in a more deliberate way. Colors communicate different feelings (eg, yellow is warm and happy, green is peaceful, red signals confidence or anger). If you have a feeling in mind, you can find the right background colors – then you can wait (using the technique from the previous tip!) until the perfect subject walks through.

12. Don't be afraid to ask strangers for a photo

Photographing people up close can be intimidating. But most people are happy to be photographed! That's essential to remember when you're going out and about with your camera.

It's especially true if you ask permission first. Simply be confident and friendly. Say, politely, “Would you mind if I take your photo?” Sometimes, you can simply gesture to your camera, and you'll get a nod or smile in return.

After all, humans are built to connect with other humans, and photography is a powerful form of connection. When you take someone's photo, you are basically saying, “I see you! You matter.” And for most people, that's a wonderful compliment.

But be ethical in your approach. Don't photograph kids or the obviously vulnerable, and if someone doesn't wish to be photographed, simply walk away. Photography is an exchange, and if you photograph someone, it should be with respect.

13. Have your settings ready

Before approaching a person to ask if you can take a photo, have your settings spot on and ready to go. You don't want to spend time fiddling around with the dials and buttons on your camera; otherwise, your subject may become annoyed and you'll lose the opportunity.

In other words, when they say “yes,” be ready to lift your arms, take a few shots, say thank you, and walk away.简单的。

Of course, you can always read the situation, and if they're open to it, you might consider sticking around and capturing a few more shots. But it's important to be ready just in case!

14. Always smile

This tip is quick but essential:

You always want to let anyone who sees you with a camera know that you are a cheerful person.这样，他们就不会介意被你拍照！如果他们确实介意——即使他们对你的问题感到愤怒——只要微笑并退后即可。

作为一名街头摄影师，您代表了所有其他街头摄影师，因此请注意不要破坏我们的集体声誉！

15. 不要要求拍摄对象微笑

根据我的经验，一张好的肖像更多地来自于拍摄对象而不是你自己。

当你要求某人微笑时，这不会很自然。相反，它会显得很勉强，而且对拍摄不利。至少，它不会让你了解那个人是谁以及他们是什么样的人。

所以不要要求微笑！您的拍摄对象将在镜头前展现他们的真实表情，无论是微笑还是悲伤。

有时，你可能会感到惊讶！

16.注意手势

你越仔细地观察人类，他们就越能通过手势展现自己。正是在那一刻——当一个手势出现并传达了一些有意义的东西时——你可以捕捉到一幅有趣的肖像。

请注意，手势仅指身体的动作。因此，一个人可以用手、眼睛、腿、手指甚至脚做出强有力的手势。

在捕捉手势时，应该特别注意时机。令人惊叹的令人回味的手势镜头和无聊、平淡、什么都没有的镜头之间的差别可能就在毫秒之内——所以要练习在正确的时刻按下快门按钮。 （您也可以考虑使用相机的连拍模式，尤其是在刚开始时。）

17. 持续练习你的方法

方法很重要。找到你的最佳状态并坚持下去。如果你只尝试一次某件事，你将永远无法掌握它。如果你经常改变方法，就需要很长时间来培养你的技能和风格。

找到您最喜欢的相机设置和镜头并持续使用它们。选择您觉得舒服的地点并经常重新访问它们。感受一下那里发生的事情以及如何拍摄它们。当光线和活动适合您时就去吧。

走近人们并询问是否可以拍摄他们的肖像。呆在阴影里，在没有通知的情况下拍照。即使您发现与陌生人交往不舒服，也可以尝试两种方法。我曾经也被石化过。然而，作为一名报纸摄影师，我必须让自己超越自己的舒适区。这让我成为了一名更好的摄影师。

18. 做你自己

当我主持研讨会时，我经常遇到对原创性的担忧。我的学生担心这个世界似乎被过度拍摄了。他们担心自己不会贡献任何有趣的东西，而且这一切以前都已经完成了。

这是思考街头人像摄影的错误方式。

当然，这个世界被大量拍照，而且已经很多年了。但世界并不是静止的。它是一个不断变化、不断移动的有机体。一切都不会一成不变，因此拍摄原创且有趣的照片的可能性实际上是无限的。

另外，虽然世界本身可能经常被拍摄，但个人却不然。有多少张街头肖像以你为拍摄对象？答案是“不多”，对吧？我的观点是，通过寻找要拍摄的人，你正在创作新的、有趣的照片。

但更重要的是，摄影是你是谁的表达。您可能会从拍摄非原创照片开始。但是，你用相机拍摄的照片越多，你就越能创造出能够全面表达你的图像：你的激情、你的经历和你看待世界的方式。这足以创建您想要的独特且有趣的照片。
